title: The transcriptional response to oxidative stress
descriptions:
Abstract:

The proposed project, "The Transcriptional Response to Oxidative Stress," seeks to elucidate the complex mechanisms governing cellular response to oxidative stress at the transcriptional level in human cells and mice. Oxidative stress, a ubiquitous and detrimental factor implicated in a variety of diseases such as neurological disorders and cancer, triggers a transcriptional response that is hypothesized to involve intricate regulation of transcription elongation and termination. This process is likely interconnected with post-translational modifications of RNA polymerase II, a key enzyme in the transcription machinery.

The project's objectives are to investigate the transcriptome-wide response to oxidative stress, to study the response following physiological induction in mice, and to provide fresh insights into the transcriptional response to oxidative stress. Additionally, the project aims to understand the mechanisms that enable RNA polymerase II to pause and resume transcription, and to explore how transcriptional response factors affect transcription-associated genome instability and neuronal cell identity.

To achieve these goals, the project will utilize advanced sequencing techniques, time-resolved proteomics, and a novel screening approach. These methodologies are expected to uncover stress-specific transcriptional response mechanisms and to confirm the hypothesis that global repression of transcription is a common cellular response to various types of stress.

This research will significantly advance our understanding of the molecular basis of oxidative stress response, with potential implications for therapeutic interventions in diseases where oxidative stress plays a key role. By providing comprehensive insights into the transcriptional dynamics under oxidative stress conditions, the project has the potential to inform the development of novel strategies to prevent or treat related pathologies.

Abstract:

The proposed project, "The Transcriptional Response to Oxidative Stress," seeks to elucidate the intricate mechanisms of cellular response to oxidative stress, with a particular focus on transcriptional regulation in human cells and physiologically induced oxidative stress in mice. The central hypothesis posits that the oxidative stress response is mediated through the dynamic regulation of transcription elongation and termination, intricately tied to post-translational modifications of RNA polymerase II. This hypothesis will be explored through three primary objectives: investigating the transcriptome-wide response in human cells, studying the response following physiological induction in mice, and expanding our understanding of the impact of transcriptional response factors on genome stability and neuronal identity. 

Employing advanced sequencing techniques and time-resolved proteomics, alongside a novel screening approach, this research aims to provide groundbreaking insights into the stress-specific mechanisms that govern transcriptional repression, the global repression patterns in response to cellular stress, and the factors that permit the cessation and resumption of transcription by RNA polymerase II. The outcomes of this study are expected to have significant implications for neurological disorders and cancer, as disruptions in the oxidative stress response are implicated in the pathogenesis of these conditions. By delivering new knowledge about the cellular response to environmental stress and its connection to disease, this project holds the potential to inform the development of innovative therapeutic strategies.

Abstract:

The proposed project titled "The transcriptional response to oxidative stress" seeks to elucidate the complex mechanisms by which human cells and mice respond to oxidative stress at the transcriptome level. The hypothesis driving this research is that oxidative stress triggers a sophisticated transcriptional response, regulating transcription elongation and termination, which are closely linked to post-translational modifications of RNA polymerase II. To test this hypothesis, the research team will leverage cutting-edge sequencing techniques, time-resolved proteomics, and a novel screening approach to investigate the global and stress-specific transcriptional repression patterns induced by oxidative stress.

The objectives of this project are multi-faceted: to thoroughly investigate the transcriptome-wide response to oxidative stress in human cells; to study the physiological induction of oxidative stress in mice; to enhance our understanding of the mechanisms that allow RNA polymerase II to pause and resume transcription; and to explore the impact of transcriptional response factors on genome instability and neuronal cell identity. Through these efforts, the project aims to provide novel insights into the transcriptional dynamics under oxidative stress conditions.

The project's relevance extends to critical areas of health and disease, including neurological disorders and cancer, where oxidative stress plays a significant role. By advancing our understanding of the transcriptional response to oxidative stress, the outcomes of this research may pave the way for the development of new therapeutic strategies for these conditions. Overall, this project promises to contribute substantially to the field of molecular biology by elucidating the complex responses of cells to environmental stressors at the transcriptional level.

Abstract:

The project titled "The Transcriptional Response to Oxidative Stress" aims to dissect the complex biological response of cells to oxidative stress, a factor implicated in the pathogenesis of neurological disorders and cancer. Oxidative stress leads to rapid and transient global repression of transcription, a process not fully understood. Our hypothesis posits that the transcriptional response to oxidative stress involves intricate regulation of transcription elongation and termination, connected to post-translational modifications of RNA polymerase II. This proposal will pursue objectives to investigate the transcriptome-wide oxidative stress response in human cells, study the response following physiological induction in mice, and elucidate the mechanisms by which transcriptional response factors influence transcription-associated genome instability and neuronal cell identity.

To achieve these goals, we will employ state-of-the-art sequencing techniques, time-resolved proteomics, and a novel screening approach. The research will provide new knowledge about the transcriptional response to oxidative stress and the stress-specific mechanisms that govern transcriptional repression at most genes. Understanding how RNA polymerase II can stop and restart transcription in response to oxidative stress is crucial for comprehending the cellular processes that contribute to the development of disease.

The significance of this research lies in its potential to reveal targets for therapeutic intervention in diseases where oxidative stress plays a key role. By advancing our understanding of the cellular response to environmental stress, this project has the potential to make a substantial impact on the treatment and management of neurological disorders and cancer. 

Keywords: Oxidative stress, transcription, RNA polymerase II, sequencing, proteomics, neurological disorders, cancer.
